Award.AwardTitle: NSF East Asia and Pacific Summer Institute (EAPSI) for FY 2013 in Japan
Award.AbstractNarration:
This action funds Michelle Lee Galloway of University of California, Berkeley to conduct a research project in Engineering during the summer of 2013 at the School of Engineering, University of Tokyo in Tokyo, Japan. The project title is "Deployment of a Gamma-ray Imaging Instrument for Characterizing Radioactive Land Contamination." The host scientist is Professor Hiroyuki Takahashi.

This research project investigates the use of a novel gamma-ray imaging instrument for the purpose of informing the environmental remediation efforts within the Fukushima prefecture. The instrument uses semiconductor detectors (cadmium zinc telluride) that are configured to allow for Compton imaging of radioactive sources. The instrument is being integrated into the existing infrastructure of the Japanese aerial monitoring program. This project assesses the capabilities of this technology for use in environmental monitoring applications. Successful deployment of the instrument allows for isotopic identification, localization and morphology of radioactive sources.

Broader impacts of an EAPSI fellowship include providing the Fellow a first-hand research experience outside the U.S.; an introduction to the science, science policy, and scientific infrastructure of the respective location; and an orientation to the society, culture and language. These activities meet the NSF goal to educate for international collaborations early in the career of its scientists, engineers, and educators, thus ensuring a globally aware U.S. scientific workforce. Furthermore, this experience provides the Fellow with a unique opportunity to learn first-hand about the impact upon and needs of the local community as a result of radioactive contamination and also how the existing scientific infrastructure, policies, and technologies are able to address these issues. The project provides the opportunity for further collaboration between the two institutions as well as facilitating technological advancement within a field that is of local, national, and global interest.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The research project funded by EAPSI investigated the use of a novel gamma-ray imaging instrument for the purpose of informing the environmental remediation efforts within the Fukushima prefecture. The instrument uses semiconductor detectors that are configured to allow for Compton imaging of radioactive sources. Compton imaging relies upon reconstruction of the path of scattered photons with a detector in order to determine the location and intensity of a radioactive source. The scattered photons are grouped together using timing information.

The instrument was integrated into the existing infrastructure of the Japanese aerial monitoring program, i.e. an unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV). This was the first time a Compton imager was deployed from a helicopter or UAV. This project assessed the capabilities of this technology for use in environmental monitoring applications, specifically from an aerial platform. 

By monitoring specific areas within the Fukushima prefecture, we found areas of higher activity (hotspots) among a diffuse background. This was determined primarily through the increased number of detected photons over time for a given survey area. However, because the radioactivity of the source and background were significantly higher than in the laboratory, i.e., ~100 x higher photons detected within a given time frame, imaging the sources with the Compton camera proved to be very difficult as the timing information could not be used to separate the hotspot photons from the background activity. The instrument deployment was successful as it proved the reliability and robustness of the gamma-ray imager under the conditions of high temperature, high humidity, and mechanical vibrations from the helicopter. The acquired data also allowed for isotopic identification of radioactive sources and background as well as provided useful information regarding improvements of the system and measuring techniques for future environmental monitoring within the Fukushima prefecture.

This research facilitated technological advancement within a field that is of local, national, and global interest. In addtion to the technical knowledge obtained from this research, this experience also established a basis for further collaboration between US and Japanese entities to address the current environmental problems in Fukushima. It provided the fellow with a unique experience to work with various Japanese institutions, to witness firsthand the effects of the Fukushima Dai-ichi nuclear accident, and and to understand how it is being addressed. Additionally, the fellow also  gained invaluable cultural and language experience as a result of participation in the EAPSI program.
